justification: Under the section on Relationship power, the review states: “The most common measure was the Sense of Power Scale (Anderson et al., 2012), which was used as a global, generalized measure of personal power …” indicating this instrument operationalizes overall relationship power.
The article reports that “The second most common was the Relationship Power Inventory (Farrell et al., 2015),” showing that this named scale is employed to quantify relationship power.

In the Sexual relationship power section it notes, “the most used measure was the 23-item Sexual Relationship Power Scale, which assesses decision-making dominance and relationship control,” linking the construct to this scale.

Early in the article the authors list measurement tools, mentioning “Household Decision-making Index (Mizan, 1993)” among “Multiple scales to measure relationship power, equality, or division of tasks,” identifying it as an instrument for decision-making power.

The same introductory list includes the “Who Does What Questionnaire (Cowan & Cowan, 1988),” illustrating that this questionnaire is used to measure how household labor is divided as a facet of power.

When describing sexual relationship power tools, the review adds that “The Sexual Communication Self-efficacy subscale assessed the subjective capability one feels in discussing risk of STIs,” showing this subscale operationalizes sexual communication efficacy.

topic_or_construct: Perceived partner approval of sexual communication
measured_by: Modified Perceived Partner Approval about Sexual Communication Scale
justification: The authors note a second single-use measure: “the Modified Perceived Partner Approval about Sexual Communication Scale (Alvarez, 2012), which is how much one's partner would accept sexual communication,” directly tying the construct to the scale.

Within the Power bases section it states that some studies “used developed items to assess the six bases of power from Raven et al. (1998)”—i.e., the Basis of Social Power Scale covering reward, coercive, expert, legitimate, referent, and informational power.
